Consent:
ONLINE PARTICIPANT INFORMATION STATEMENT

Online survey participants

Residents’ insights into the 2019-2020 fire season’s impacts on soil and vegetation, perceptions, and behaviours in NSW, Australia.

Dr. Miriam Muñoz-Rojas, Chief Investigator

 

1. What is the research study about?

You are invited to take part in this research study, which aims to assess the impacts of the 2019-2020 fire season on 1) soil and native vegetation responses, 2) perceptions, and 3) behaviours across New South Wales (NSW). This study is important because it will provide a broad assessment of the fires across a large area in a short amount of time, filling a gap in the current knowledge about the impacts of abnormally severe fires, such as those experienced during the Black Summer, in the Australian landscape. 



We hope to use information we get from this research study to benefit others who may be impacted by fire in the future. This research may promote funding and support for future studies and programs such as the Hotspots Fire Project. Furthermore, by using the knowledge gained from this study, Hotspots can continue to improve their training styles and content and support expansion of workshop delivery efficiently and effectively to meet community needs.



2. Who is conducting this research? 

The study is being carried out by... 

Researchers: Dr. Miriam Muñoz-Rojas, chief investigator, Dr. Mark Ooi, Senior Research Fellow, and Ms. Mercedes Ondik, PhD student, Faculty of Science and School of Biological, Earth, and Environmental Sciences, UNSW.

Collaborators: The NSW Rural Fire Service and Nature Conservation Council of NSW will send the initial recruitment email to members of the Hotspots Fire project mailing list and will have no further involvement in the research.

Research Funder: This research is being funded by the UNSW Centre for Ecosystem Sciences.



3. Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria: 

Before you decide to participate in this research study, we need to ensure that it is ok for you to take part.

The research study is looking recruit people who meet the following criteria:

• Over 18 years old 

• A resident of New South Wales 

• Have had direct or indirect experience with the 2019-2020 bushfires

Individuals who do not meet the inclusion criteria above are not eligible to participate.



4. Do I have to take part in this research study? 

Participation in any research study is voluntary. If you do not want to take part, you do not have to. If you decide to take part and later change your mind, you are free to withdraw from the study at any stage.



If you decide you want to take part in the research study, you will be asked to:

• Read this information carefully (email research team to ask questions if necessary);

• Complete the online questionnaire.



5. What does participation in this research require, and are there any risks involved? 

If you decide to take part in the research study, we will ask you to complete an online questionnaire. The questionnaire will ask you questions about the impacts of the 2019-2020 fire season on perceptions, behaviours, and soil and native vegetation responses in your community and how these impacts compare to previous fire seasons. It should take approximately 15 minutes to complete.



Additional Costs and Reimbursement: There are no costs associated with participating in this portion of the research project, nor will you be paid. However, if you choose to participate in the interview portion of the study, you may receive a copy of "Ocean Shores to Desert Dunes: The Native Vegetation of New South Wales and the ACT" by Professor David A. Keith.



Psychological Distress: You may feel that some of the questions we ask are stressful or upsetting. If you do not wish to answer a question, you may skip it and go to the next question, or you may stop immediately. If you become upset or distressed as a result of your participation in the research project, a number of free contactable support services are included at section 9. Any counselling or support will be provided by qualified staff who are not members of the research team. This counselling will be provided free of charge.



6. What will happen to information about me? 

Completion and submission of the online questionnaire is an indication of your consent. By answering ‘Yes’ to the question, ‘Do you consent to participating in this survey?’, you are providing your permission for the research team to collect and use non-identifiable information about you for the research study. This information will be collated into a report which will be provided to the Hotspots Fire Project and a research article that will be published in a scientific journal. You may request a copy of the report and publication at the end of the online survey.



The research team will store the data collected from you for this research project for a minimum of 5 years after the publication of the research results. The information about you will be stored in a non-identifiable format where your identity will be unknown on a UNSW password protected OneDrive only accessible to the approved research investigators.



7. How and when will I find out what the results of the research study are? 

The research team intend to publish and report the results of the research. All Information will be published in a way that will not identify you.



If you would like to receive a copy of the report and publication, you can let the research team know by emailing the team (see contact details in section 9 below) or by providing your preferred contact details when asked at the end of the survey. We will only use your contact details to send you the results of the research.  



8. What if I want to withdraw from the research study? 

If you do consent to participate, you may withdraw at any time. You can do this by closing the questionnaire. If you withdraw from the research, any information that has already been collected will be destroyed. Once you have submitted the questionnaire however, we will not be able to withdraw your responses as the questionnaire is anonymous.



The information you provide is personal information for the purposes of the Privacy and Personal Information Protection Act 1998 (NSW). You have the right of access to personal information held about you by the University, the right to request correction and amendment of it, and the right to make a compliant about a breach of the Information Protection Principles as contained in the PPIP Act. Further information on how the University protects personal information is available in the UNSW Privacy Management Plan.



9. What should I do if I have further questions about my involvement in the research study? 

The person you may need to contact will depend on the nature of your query. If you require further information regarding this study or if you have any problems which may be related to your involvement in the study, you can contact the following member/s of the research team:



Research Team Contact Details 

Mercedes Ondik, PhD Student, UNSW

Q21: Fire ecology (how vegetation/ ecosystems respond to fire within the landscape)
Q26: Installed two purpose built fire bunkers despite resistance from the RFS
Q27: I thought upper and mid level RFS planning was poor. Conflicting information and poor strategies pushed us the develop our own plan. I do not blame climatic change for this event at all. That is a convenient excuse. Poor interwoven management practices and traditional thinking were far more of contributory factors

Q26: Built fire proof house

Q16: how on earth would the great majority of people have accurate/useful answers to any of these?
Q21_5_TEXT: what is possible in the future. A near by fire chief (Bilpin) who lost his orchards in the fire said he no longer has any idea of what the future holds re bush fires, as he had never considered that his orchards would ever be in danger of fire.
Q23: as the fires were much more extensive eg across NSW than previously, obviously the impact of property etc                               would be greater than before!!??
Q26: undertaken more clearing in the direction fires usually come.
Q27: As someone who has had some experience in research, 'research' such as this terrifies me.  as to how it WILL be used. Surely ANY 'research' based on surveys, is at best, only vaguely useful for any purpose, apart from obtaining a 'research' degree..

Q16: What was once largely grassy woodlands has had the crown totally removed and it is in many places very dense thickets of Wattle and other shrubs and many vines i.e. Hardenbergia, Clematis etc
Q21_5_TEXT: this does not allow me to select multiples though the heading states it does. All of the above
Q23: not all of the damaging fires were due to natural causes and many were deliberately done by inexperienced RFS crews and also experienced crews who were unable to contend with the extreme conditions of the season where traditional methods were not always as helpful as they may have been in other seasons leading to much more area and damage being done
Q26: the implemented control burns that were managed poorly have created a situation where the ensuing fire risks for many years from now will be much higher than if the deliberate burns were not put in in the first place. My fire risk now is exponentially greater than if the planned burns were not put in.
Q27: There is a need to better understand that methods need to be changed under different fire risk and that our traditional fire fighting methods are not always appropriate and in fact can lead to greater fire risk in ensuing years. There needs to be a reevaluation of techniques.

Q26: I live on a rural land sharing co-operative with 78 shares with mixed attitudes towards fire management from total apathy to very concerned. I continue to advocate fire that bushfire preparedness is everyone’s responsibility.
Q27: I did put in a request for information on how to go about getting Hot Spots session for our cooperative but didn’t hear back. I will follow up again this year year. The 1600 acre property shares its border with Limeburners National Park. High risk for bushfires. The December 2017 fire impacted the property and we were lucky have the full support of RFS as there were no other fires around. We were spared in 2019/20 but it came very close and it was a nervous time with fires in Telegraph Point.

Q16: While I don't have the answers on soil nutrients after the fire anything that came up was on steroids and we got weeds we had never seen before popping up all over.  The Lomandra along the river while burnt very black held the banks and prevented a lot of erosion plus very quickly put coir rolls donated by Land services on the most vulnerable point on the river bank and they worked but lots of black ash and soil came down with the flood from higher up and settled over the paddocks next door that are flood plain.  Veg crops etc did very well in the next year and in fact the stone and pom fruits overdid it.  Very few bees about to staart with and less in this second year of La Nina
Q21_5_TEXT: already well aware of bushfire threat and climate change and the short but very severe drought really played a major role and the effect of a large ( slightly uncontrolled ) hazard reduction burn nearby and between me and the first impact of the fires had no effect and the fire may even have sped uo throught the area which was done 14months before the fires hit.  Generally amazed at the ability of native and exotic vegetation's ability to recover aftere the fires helped by the rain first coming in a light couple of showers which got some grass growth before 2 large floods hit so reducing the expected erosion.
Q23: Areas of native heathland and rainforest on the Budawangs range have not recovered as well and the route across the Sassafras mountain is still horrible.
Q26: Due to loss of house and numerous other factors such as age I decided to move on to a smaller property nearer family but I am using some of the experience to influence the protection of the new residence.  ie no outside power points that can't be protected from fire and bushfire mesh along the house soil boundary.  Have to cater for fire and termite prevention
Q27: From my point of view I believe more rapid clearing of the burnt structures and dangerous trees would have helped mental health more than chat fests.  CVoming out each morning from a temporary cabin and seeing the burnt remains of the house and property was not a good thing especially once Covid hit and we had little other escape from the sight.  Being able to get on with property repairs as I did not lose my shed ( or only some small ones ) meant I could at least be doing something and it got me out looking for signs of regrowth and gathering the remains of pipes etc.  Also learnt that all water pipes need to be underground.  I was lucky and kept my solar energy system and internet connection ( satellite )

Hotspots could encourage greater community participation and provide an opportunity for RFS volunteers to learn and practice better low intensity back burn procedures.
